content:
Welcome to 6.00.1x, INSTRUCTOR-PACED!

Courseware

At this time, you can access courseware (videos, problems, discussions, exams, and a Progress tab to track your grade).

If this is your first time on the edX platform, please begin by viewing this welcome sequence that will cover important details on how to use the edX courseware and what to expect. You will be able to view course videos and problems under the Courseware tab (at the top left).

Important Note for Everyone: If you have not upgraded to a Verified Certificate by the deadline, you will not have access to the exams (Midterm and Final).

Deadlines

This course is instructor-led, which means that we have deadlines you'll need to meet, with something due approximately every week. All deadlines are in the Calendar. Most notably, the midterm and final exam take place over 4 specific days, in an 8-hour time limit of your choosing within those 4 days. All deadlines are in the UTC time zone.

Forum

There is a discussion board - accessible 24 hours a day - where you can get help other students in the class. Please take the time to read our forum guidelines before posting (on the right). Do not post solutions/code related to problem sets and exams. Any such posts will be removed.

Love helping others?

We would love to have community TAs for this course! If you know programming already and are dedicated and interested to help other students on the forum for the duration of this course, let us know by replying to this post pinned on the forum. Guidelines for CTAs are available in a document on the right.

Handouts

Information about the class - including a syllabus and the course philosophy - are on the right. Please also take the time to look through all the course handouts we have provided for you on the right.

Getting a Certificate

Access to the exams (Midterm and Final) is restricted. You must upgrade to a Verified Certificate by the deadline on the course page to view this content.

Social Media

Our Official Facebook Page
Our Official Facebook Group
Our Official Twitter Page @mitx6001x #mitx6001x
Our Coding Sessions page on Youtube

We hope you enjoy!

The faculty and course staff are looking forward to working with you this term, and we hope that you will have a great time learning about programming and computation. We are excited to have you all join us!

- Ana and the 6.00.1x staff

Week 2

[Graders back up: Sept 13 02:30 UTC] Graders are back up.
[Graders Down: Sept 13 00:30 UTC] EdX has been notified. We will update this when we know more!

UPDATE: As you may know, we offer optional study groups on MIT’s Unhangouts. To help you out with psets currently out, we will be holding two official study sessions this weekend! Community TAs and staff will be online to answer your pset questions.

  • Saturday Sept 10 at 13:00 UTC
  • Saturday Sept 10 at 20:00 UTC

Join us here!

We hope you are enjoying the course so far! We have released the next set of materials:

  • Lectures on Simple Algorithms and on Functions
  • Problem Set 2 will test you on coding up some simple algorithms applied to a real-life problem and is due Tuesday Sept 27 at 23:30 UTC.
  • Problem Set 1 is already out and due Tuesday Sept 20 at 23:30 UTC.

Take note that these deadlines are stated in UTC. To see deadlines in your local timezone, go to your edX Dashboard settings and set the timezone (top right -> click the small arrow -> Account -> Timezone).

If you are new to programming, you may find the following resources helpful:

  • the Python Tutor as a way to step through code (to understand and debug)
  • numerous other resources

For extra practice, we offer a set of "complete programming experiences" in the Courseware. You will write code that will be autograded for correctness and then be graded by your peers for coding style!

Happy coding!

Week 3

UNHANGOUTS Update: We had a good turnout the first time we did it, so we will hold it every Saturday until the course ends, except for weekends during the quiz and final exam! Community TAs and staff will be online at 13:00 UTC and 20:00 UTC (for about an hour, each time). Join us here!

New lectures are out! This week, we will look at new data types: lists and dictionaries. With these two objects, you will be able to write more interesting and involved programs. Problem Set 3, due on Tuesday Oct 11 at 23:30 UTC, will test your knowledge of these objects and you will implement a hangman game!

Remember that this course will challenge your ability to think critically. Lectures introduce you to concepts. Problem Sets simulate how it would be to solve programming problems and code in real life -- you will have to use the hints we give you, other online resources, and you will have to take breaks to give your brain a chance to absorb the problem.

Everyone can benefit from the course discussion forum -- you are not alone! We have community TAs (students just like you!) who have been through this already and are volunteering their time to help you succeed as well.

  • if you feel frustrated, take a few breaths and read this motivating post from your fellow student
  • re-read the course philosophy -- if you succeed in this course, it is a great achievement!
  • we have other social networks if you do not want to use the course forum: Facebook Group and Slack (see right hand side)
  • use the Python Tutor to step through your code

Finally, we would like to make a small correction regarding a grading policy inconsistency:

  • to receive a Verified Certificate, you need at least 55% overall
  • if you are taking this course for credit (Charter Oak, for example), you must be signed up for a Verified Certificate and achieve at least 65% in the course.
  • you can switch to/from a certificate on Tuesday Oct 4 at 23:30 UTC

Please give us any feedback you may have at any point in this forum thread.

No Materials

No new materials out this week. Catch up on your problem sets!

Week 4 and Quiz Information

The next set of materials are out: lectures on debugging, exceptions, and assertions. Problem Set 4, where you will implement a word game is also available.

Upcoming deadlines:

  • Problem Set 2, due Tuesday September 27 at 23:30 UTC
  • Problem Set 3, due Tuesday October 11 at 23:30 UTC
  • Problem Set 4, due Tuesday October 18 at 23:30 UTC
  • Switch to/from Verified Certificate, Tuesday Oct 4 at 23:30 UTC
  • Quiz available from Friday Sept 30 to Tuesday Oct 4 at 23:30 UTC, more info below

Quiz Information

  • The quiz will be available starting from Friday Sept 30 at 14:00 UTC.
  • The quiz will close on Tuesday Oct 4 at 23:30 UTC.
  • The quiz has no time limit, but you must submit your answers before the deadline.

Materials:

The quiz covers everything (video lectures, finger exercises, and problem sets) up to and including Lecture 7 on Debugging. You can use the textbook. You can use the internet to look up documentation and to clarify your knowledge of certain topics, as long as you are not deliberately looking up answers to the questions.

Practice:

We do not post practice exams, but you can check out the textbook finger exercises or MIT OpenCourseware for more coding practice questions. Also check out the Additional Python Resources for fun websites.

If you are still struggling with some concepts, check out a few optional tutorial videos on our Youtube channel for some of the more confusing topics in the course.

  • on strings
  • on tuples, lists, and mutability
  • on dictionaries and aliasing
  • on variable scope
  • on importing modules and indentation

During the Quiz:

The format will be some multiple choice and some coding questions. You can start anytime and you will only receive a grade for whatever you submit before the quiz deadline. For multiple choice questions, you will only have one try to submit. For coding questions, hit Save to save what you have written so far and hit Check to submit to the grader. You will only have 10 tries to submit code. We limit this number so that the graders do not get overloaded with so many submissions in such a short period of time. Please do not discuss the quiz on any of our social networks.

Check the Course Home page periodically. It is by far the fastest way the staff has to communicate delays, corrections, and changes. The forum is closed during the quiz. You can see past posts but not ask questions.

Wishing success to everyone!

Quiz Closed

Hint on Problem 8. If you got 18/20 and think you have the right code, consider any stylistically redundant parts in your code -- specifically, are you checking whether some boolean expression == True or == False? Your number of attempts for this question have been reset.

||||| Quiz Countdown Timer |||||

  • The quiz will be available starting from Friday Sept 30 at 14:00 UTC.
  • The quiz will close on Tuesday Oct 4 at 23:30 UTC.
  • The quiz has no time limit, but you must submit your answers before the deadline.

Materials:

The quiz covers everything (video lectures, finger exercises, and problem sets) up to and including Lecture 7 on Debugging. You can use the textbook. You can use the internet to look up documentation and to clarify your knowledge of certain topics, as long as you are not deliberately looking up answers to the questions.

We do not post practice exams, but you can check out the textbook finger exercises or MIT OpenCourseware for more coding practice questions. Also check out the Additional Python Resources for fun websites.

If you are still struggling with some concepts, check out a few optional tutorial videos on our Youtube channel for some of the more confusing topics in the course.

  • on strings
  • on tuples, lists, and mutability
  • on dictionaries and aliasing
  • on variable scope
  • on importing modules and indentation

During the Quiz:

The format will be some multiple choice and some coding questions. You can start anytime and you will only receive a grade for whatever you submit before the quiz deadline. For multiple choice questions, you will only have one try to submit. For coding questions, hit Save to save what you have written so far and hit Check to submit to the grader. You will only have 10 tries to submit code. We limit this number so that the graders do not get overloaded with so many submissions in such a short period of time. Please do not discuss the quiz on any of our social networks.

Check the Course Home page periodically. It is by far the fastest way the staff has to communicate delays, corrections, and changes. The forum is closed during the quiz. You can see past posts but not ask questions.

Wishing success to everyone!

Week 5

In this week's lecture set, you will be learning about object oriented programming and classes. This is a tough concept to grasp, so make sure you do the finger exercises for practice! In Problem Set 6 you will be using what you learned to code a Caesar cipher to encrypt and decrypt secret messages!

Deadlines coming up:
  • Problem Set 3 is due next week on Tuesday October 11 at 23:30 UTC
  • Problem Set 4 is due on Tuesday October 18 at 23:30 UTC
  • Problem Set 5 is due on Thursday October 27 at 23:30 UTC

Week 6

The next set of lectures is more theoretical than what we have been doing so far. We will be looking at the efficiency and complexity of programs. Additionally, we will look at algorithms to search and sort lists. There is a final non-coding problem set up.

Upcoming deadlines:

  • Problem Set 4 is due next week on Tuesday October 18 at 23:30 UTC
  • Problem Set 5 is due on Thursday October 27 at 23:30 UTC
  • Problem Set 6 is due on Thursday October 27 at 23:30 UTC

Week 7

The final lecture set is available, on using a Python library to plot graphs of data.

Upcoming deadlines:

  • Problem Set 5 is due on Thursday October 27 at 23:30 UTC
  • Problem Set 6 is due on Thursday October 27 at 23:30 UTC
  • Final Exam on Friday Oct 28 to Tuesday Nov 1 (more details next week)

We have a few announcements as we are wrapping up the course:

  • The final exam will be available at the end of this week -- information is below
  • Problem Set 5 is due Thursday October 27 at 23:30 UTC
  • Problem Set 6 is due Thursday October 27 at 23:30 UTC
  • We have Python Revision Notes available to help you as you do the final exam
  • We have supplementary tutorial videos on some key concepts in the course on our Youtube page

Exam Information

  • The exam will be available starting from Friday October 28 at 14:00 UTC
  • The exam will close on Tuesday Nov 1 at 23:30 UTC
  • The exam has no time limit, but you must submit your answers before the deadline

Materials:

The exam covers everything (video lectures, finger exercises, and problem sets) in the course. You can use the textbook. You can use the internet to look up documentation and to clarify your knowledge of certain topics, as long as you are not deliberately looking up answers to the questions.

Practice:

We do not post practice exams, but you can check out the textbook finger exercises or MIT OpenCourseware for more coding practice questions. Also check out the Additional Python Resources from the Home page.

During the Exam:

The format will be some multiple choice and some coding questions. You can start anytime and you will only receive a grade for whatever you submit before the exam deadline. For multiple choice questions, you will only have one try to submit. For coding questions, hit Save to save what you have written so far and hit Submit to submit to the grader. You will only have 10 tries to submit code. We limit this number so that the graders do not get overloaded with so many submissions in such a short period of time. Please do not discuss the exam on the Facebook/Slack group page.

Check the course Home page periodically. It is by far the fastest way the staff has to communicate delays, corrections, and changes. The forum is closed during the exam. You can see past posts but not ask questions.

Wishing success to everyone!

Unit 3

UPDATE: Jan 29, 13:00: Grading queue is fixed.

UPDATE: Jan 28, 20:00: Grading queue is having issues processing submissions. edX has been alerted. We will update this page when we hear back from them. When the grading queue is fixed, we will reset everyones attempts back to 0 for Problem Set 2.

Just a quick reminder that your first problem set is due in less than 36 hours, on Thursday Jan 26 at 23:30 UTC. Make sure you are familiar with what time this is in your own time zone. What time is it in UTC right now? Note that to see deadlines in your local timezone on edX, you can go to your edX Dashboard settings and set the timezone (top right -> click the small arrow -> Account -> Timezone).

New lectures are already out! This week, we will look at new data types: lists and dictionaries. With these two objects, you will be able to write more interesting and involved programs. Problem Set 3 will test your knowledge of these objects and you will implement a hangman game!

Some upcoming due dates:

  • Problem Set 1 due on Thursday Jan 26 at 23:30 UTC
  • Problem Set 2 due on Thursday Feb 2 at 23:30 UTC (next week)
  • Problem Set 3 due on Thursday Feb 9 at 23:30 UTC (in 2 weeks)
  • Switch to/from a certificate on Tuesday Feb 7 at 23:30 UTC

Remember that this course will challenge your ability to think critically. Lectures introduce you to concepts. Problem Sets simulate how it would be to solve programming problems and code in real life -- you will have to use the hints we give you, other online resources, and you will have to take breaks to give your brain a chance to absorb the problem.

Everyone can benefit from the course discussion forum -- you are not alone! We have community TAs (students just like you!) who have been through this already and are volunteering their time to help you succeed as well.

  • if you feel frustrated, take a few breaths and read this motivating post from your fellow student
  • re-read the course philosophy -- if you succeed in this course, it is a great achievement!
  • we have other social networks if you do not want to use the course forum: Facebook Group and Slack
    • use the Python Tutor to step through your code
  • Please give us any feedback you may have at any point in this forum thread.

Unit 4 and Quiz Information

Graders Working Again, Feb 12 17:40 UTC: All quiz problems have had their number of attempts reset back to 0. Note that we will not give any quiz extensions if the graders go down closer to the quiz deadline -- please try to work on the quiz early!

Graders Down During Quiz, Feb 12 16:00 UTC: edX has been notified. We will update this page when the issue is resolved and reset attempts for coding problems to 0. In the meantime, you can work locally on other problems and when the graders are up you can submit.

Certificate Update: The deadline to sign up for a certificate has been extended by 24 hours. If you would like a certificate, please upgrade before Friday Feb 10 at 23:00 UTC.

Unit 4 is now available, with Problem Set 4 due on Thursday Feb 23 at 23:30 UTC.

Also, there is a quiz starting in a couple of days! You do not have to finish Unit 4 before working on the quiz.

Quiz Information

  • The quiz will be available starting from Friday Feb 10 at 14:00 UTC.
  • The quiz will close on Tuesday Feb 14 at 23:30 UTC.
  • The quiz has no time limit, but you must submit your answers before the deadline.

Materials:

The quiz covers everything (video lectures, finger exercises, and problem sets) up to and including Lecture 7 on Debugging. You can use the textbook. You can use the internet to look up documentation and to clarify your knowledge of certain topics, as long as you are not deliberately looking up answers to the questions.

Practice:

We do not post practice exams, but you can check out the textbook finger exercises or MIT OpenCourseware for more coding practice questions. Also check out the Additional Python Resources for fun websites.

During the Quiz:

The format will be some multiple choice and some coding questions. You can start anytime and you will only receive a grade for whatever you submit before the quiz deadline. For multiple choice questions, you will only have one try to submit. For coding questions, hit Save to save what you have written so far and hit Check to submit to the grader. You will only have 10 tries to submit code. We limit this number so that the graders do not get overloaded with so many submissions in such a short period of time. Please do not discuss the quiz on any of our social networks.

Check the Course Home page periodically. It is by far the fastest way the staff has to communicate delays, corrections, and changes. The forum is closed during the quiz. You can see past posts but not ask questions.

Wishing success to everyone!

Unit 5

We have released the next set of lectures and problem set. You will be learning about object oriented programming and classes. This is a tough concept to grasp, so make sure you do the finger exercises for practice! In Problem Set 6 you will be using what you learned to code a Caesar cipher to encrypt and decrypt secret messages!

Deadlines coming up:

  • Problem Set 4 is due next week on Thursday Feb 23 at 23:30 UTC
  • Problem Set 5 is due on Thursday March 2 at 23:30 UTC

Unit 6

edX Grader Working 20:00 UTC: Issue resolved.

edX Grader Down 19:00 UTC: edX is aware of this issue. We'll update this page when they have resolved it.

We have released the last set of lectures. They are on applications of classes to plotting! If you plan in taking 6.00.2x after this, these lectures will give you an idea of the kinds of things you'll be seeing in that course.

Deadlines coming up:

  • Problem Set 5 is due on Thursday March 2 at 23:30 UTC
  • Problem Set 6 is due on Thursday March 9 at 23:30 UTC

Final Exam NOW CLOSED

We have a few announcements as we are wrapping up the course:

  • The final exam will be available at the end of this week -- information is below
  • Problem Set 6 is due Thursday March 9 at 23:30 UTC
  • We have Python Revision Notes available to help you as you do the final exam
  • We have supplementary tutorial videos on some key concepts in the course on our Youtube page

If you liked the course and want to keep learning computer science, check out 6.00.2x: Intro to Computational Thinking and Data Science!

------

Exam Information

  • The exam will be available starting from Friday March 10 at 14:00 UTC
  • The exam will close on Tuesday March 14 at 23:30 UTC
  • The exam has no time limit, but you must submit your answers before the deadline

Materials:

The exam covers everything (video lectures, finger exercises, and problem sets) in the course. You can use the textbook. You can use the internet to look up documentation and to clarify your knowledge of certain topics, as long as you are not deliberately looking up answers to the questions.

Practice:

We do not post practice exams, but you can check out the textbook finger exercises or MIT OpenCourseware for more coding practice questions. Also check out the Additional Python Resources from Updates and News.

During the Exam:

The format will be some multiple choice and some coding questions. You can start anytime and you will only receive a grade for whatever you submit before the exam deadline. For multiple choice questions, you will only have one try to submit. For coding questions, hit Save to save what you have written so far and hit Submit to submit to the grader. You will only have 10 tries to submit code. We limit this number so that the graders do not get overloaded with so many submissions in such a short period of time. Please do not discuss the exam on the Facebook/Slack group page.

Check the this page periodically. It is by far the fastest way the staff has to communicate delays, corrections, and changes. The forum is closed during the exam. You can see past posts but not ask questions.

Wishing success to everyone!

Final Remarks

With the final exam over, you have until 23:30 on Wednesday March 15 to submit any remaining finger exercises -- remember that they are worth 10% of the grade! We also ask that you take a few minutes to complete our exit survey. Your responses are greatly appreciated.

Certificates will be generated within a couple of weeks and will be available on your edX dashboard -- to see whether you have reached the cutoff for a certificate, you can click the Progress link in the course. Course materials (videos, exercises, thesandbox) will continue to be available after the course ends.

The staff would like to extend their thanks to all the students for your participation and effort. We would also like to especially thank all the Community TAs who have had an incredibly helpful presence on the course forum, the Facebook page, the Slack group, and with preparing extra practice materials.

We hope you enjoyed the course! If you are wondering what to do next, check out 6.00.2x! It has already started but there is a lot of time to catch up -- the first problem set isn't due until a couple of weeks from now.

Whatever your next steps, as always, happy coding from the 6.00.1x staff!

Unit 2

We hope you are enjoying the course so far! We have already released the next set of materials:

  • Lectures on Simple Algorithms and on Python Functions
  • Problem Set 1 is due Thursday June 15 at 23:30 UTC.
  • Problem Set 2 will test you on coding up some simple algorithms applied to a real-life problem and is due Thursday June 22 at 23:30 UTC. Remember that this time will vary in your local time zone. What time is it in UTC right now?

If you are new to programming, you may find the following resources helpful:

  • the Python Tutor as a way to step through code (to understand and debug)
  • numerous other resources in these forum posts: tips, motivation, resources, and how to succeed (from one of our community TAs)
  • a compilation of forum tutorials from our Community TAs

Wishing you all success!

Unit 3

Update (June 21): Problem Set 2 Virtual Office Hours with a Community TA

I'll be holding "virtual" office hours again—focusing this time on pset2. If you want to join in, you can click on the following link: this link.

The meeting will start at 20:00 (Cambridge, MA) time on Wednesday, June 21st. That is midnight GMT. It should run between 1~1.5 hrs.

I'll be using the Zoom platform again. If you don't have that software installed already, you will be prompted to download and install when you try to join the meeting.

Update (June 14): Problem Set 1 Virtual Office Hours with a Community TA

For those of you still struggling with problem #3 of pset 1, I thought I'd try an experiment and hold "video office hours". The purpose is not to give you the "correct" code, but rather to guide you with some hints to get to the answer(s) yourself. I'll be taking some questions and then mainly sharing my screen and interacting with participants that way. If you want to join in, you can click on this link.

The meeting will start at 20:00 (Cambridge, MA) time on Wednesday, June 14th. That is midnight GMT. I've scheduled it for 2 hrs but would love to wrap up in 1 hr or less.

I've set up the meeting using the Zoom platform. If you don't have that software installed already, you will be prompted to download and install. It's the most stable video system I've used so far but you will need a good Internet connection to participate. The software is available on Mac, PC, and Linux as well as Android and iOS.

Please note that I will be recording this so (1) if you can't attend, perhaps you can watch the recording and (2) by participating, you agree to be recorded (voice, video, screen, etc.).

Finally, if something goes technically very wrong during the meeting, or if you cannot connect properly, please remember this is an experiment and we can't guarantee anything.

See you soon,
Thomas Ballatore

  • Problem Set 1 due on Thursday June 15 at 23:30 UTC
  • Problem Set 2 due on Thursday June 22 at 23:30 UTC (next week)
  • Problem Set 3 due on Thursday June 29 at 23:30 UTC (in 2 weeks)
  • Switch to/from a certificate on Tuesday June 26 at 23:30 UTC

Make sure you are familiar with what time these due dates map to in your own time zone. What time is it in UTC right now? Note that to see deadlines in your local timezone on edX, you can go to your edX Dashboard settings and set the timezone (top right -> click the small arrow -> Account -> Timezone).
